column4: ```turtle@prefix ex: <http://example.org/art#> .@prefix rdf: <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#> .@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .ex:Art rdf:type rdfs:Class .ex:Painting rdf:type rdfs:Class ;           rdfs:subClassOf ex:Art .ex:Sculpture rdf:type rdfs:Class ;             rdfs:subClassOf ex:Art .ex:Genre rdf:type rdfs:Class .ex:Impressionism rdf:type ex:Genre .ex:Renaissance rdf:type ex:Genre .ex:portrait rdf:type rdfs:Property ;            rdfs:domain ex:Painting ;            rdfs:range rdfs:Literal .ex:artist rdf:type rdfs:Property ;            rdfs:domain ex:Art ;            rdfs:range rdfs:Literal .ex:hasGenre rdf:type rdfs:Property ;            rdfs:domain ex:Art ;            rdfs:range ex:Genre .ex:MonaLisa rdf:type ex:Painting ;            ex:artist "Leonardo da Vinci" ;            ex:hasGenre ex:Renaissance . ex:StarryNight rdf:type ex:Painting ;               ex:artist "Vincent van Gogh" ;               ex:hasGenre ex:Impressionism .ex:TheThinker rdf:type ex:Sculpture ;              ex:artist "Auguste Rodin" .```This ontology describes a simple model of art, where art consists of two subclasses: Painting and Sculpture. column4: An ontology for the domain of art might look as follows:1. Art:   - Definition: A means of expressing or communicating emotions, ideas, and viewpoints that is often visual or auditory in nature.2. Types of Art:    - Visual Art: Art forms that create works primarily visual in nature.        - Painting: Art made by application of paint, pigment, or the like, often in a picture or design.        - Sculpture: Process or action of carving or molding figures or shapes in the round or in relief.        - Photography: Art or practice of taking and processing photos.        - Film: Motion picture as an art form.        - Installations: Large-scale, mixed-media artworks.        - Architecture: The art or practice of designing and constructing buildings.        - Digital Art: Art made with digital technology.    - Performing Art: Arts or skills that require a performance in front of a public audience.        - Theatre: A place where plays are usually presented.        - Dance: The movement of the body in a rhythmic way.        - Music: Vocal or instrumental sounds combined in such a way as to produce beauty of form, harmony, and expression of emotion.    - Literary Art: Artistic expression through writing.        - Poetry: Composition in verse or some similar patterned arrangement of language.        - Prose Fiction: Written language in its ordinary form, without metrical structure.    - Folk Art: Artistic creations made by cultural communities for their own enjoyment.        - Weaving: Art of forming fabric or cloth by interlacing threads.        - Pottery: Art of making vessels of clay.3. Artists:     - Definition: A person who practices or performs any of the creative arts, like a sculptor, novelist, poet, or filmmaker.   4. Art Styles:    - Realism: Artistic style in which the artist attempts to depict subjects truthfully.    - Impressionism: Style of painting which seeks to capture a feeling or experience rather than achieve accurate depiction.    - Expressionism: Artistic movement in which artists sought to express meaning or emotional experience rather than physical reality.    - Cubism: Artistic style in which forms are abstracted by using an analytical approach to the object. 5. Art Movements:    - Renaissance: Period in European art that emerged in the later Middle Ages.    - Baroque: Period of artistic style that used exaggerated motion and clear, detailed, and dramatic use of light.    - Romanticism: Movement in the arts emphasizing inspiration, subjectivity, and individual genius.    - Modernism: Artistic movement that arose from wide-scale and far-reaching transformations in society during the late 19th and early 20th centuries.    - Postmodernism: Artistic movement characterized by the self-conscious use of earlier styles and conventions.6. Art Institutions:    - Museum: Institution preserving and exhibiting works of artistic, historical, or scientific interest.    - Art Schools: Educational institution with a primary focus on the visual arts.    - Art Galleries: Space where art is exhibited.7. Art Medium:    - Definition: Materials used to create a work of art.        - Oil Paint: Type of slow-drying paint that consists of particles of pigment suspended in oil.        - Watercolor: Paint that is made soluble in water by the addition of a binder and a diluent.        - Acrylic Paint: Type of paint that is made from acrylic polymer emulsions.        - Clay: Stiff, sticky fine-grained substance that can be molded when wet.        - Film: Medium used to create motion pictures.        - Digital: Art made on/with a computer or computer program.8. Art Techniques:    - Sketching: Quick, freehand drawing.    - Modeling: Sculptural technique where materials are worked by the artist's hands.    - Collage: Art technique where the artwork is made from assembling different forms.9. Art Criticism:    - Definition: The discussion or evaluation of visual art.10. Art History:    - Definition: Study of objects of art in their historical development and stylistic contexts. Please note, each of the above categories would have multiple subcategories and concepts associated with them. The ontology of "art" is vast with many overlapping and interconnected ideas and concepts.
